title: RS22607
content: It is a federal crime to assault, kidnap, or kill a federal judge or their family members with the intent to obstruct or retaliate for the judge's duties. This protection extends to federal law enforcement officers, prosecutors, and any federal officer or employee. The penalties for obstructing federal officers or employees are increased under Section 207 of P.L. 110-177, with maximum penalties for voluntary manslaughter raised to 15 years and for involuntary manslaughter to 8 years. Other federal statutes also adopt this penalty structure. The federal obstruction of justice statutes provide protection for witnesses and potential witnesses in federal judicial, Congressional, and administrative proceedings. These statutes outlaw murder, assaults, and threats intended to prevent or influence a witness' testimony or retaliate for past testimony. The penalties for crimes against federal witnesses are the same as for crimes against federal officials, with assault and conspiracy carrying slightly more severe penalties. The penalties for crimes against federal witnesses are the same as for crimes against federal officials, with assault and conspiracy carrying slightly more severe penalties. Sections 205 and 206 of P.L. 110-177 increase the maximum penalty for witness tampering or retaliation involving physical force from 20 years to 30 years, threats of physical force from 10 years to 20 years, and harassment from 1 year to 3 years. Section 204 adds a venue provision to witness retaliation offenses in 18 U.S.C. 1513, allowing prosecution in either the place of violation or where the proceeding occurred. The Supreme Court has raised concerns about prosecuting offenses outside of where they occur. Federal criminal laws prohibit the misuse of firearms and other dangerous weapons, such as in attacks at federal facilities. For instance, 18 U.S.C. 930 prohibits using a firearm in a fatal attack at a federal facility, with penalties similar to those for murder and manslaughter. The federal criminal laws prohibit the misuse of firearms and dangerous weapons at federal facilities. Section 203 of P.L. 110-177 expands the prohibition to include possession of other dangerous weapons in addition to firearms within federal courthouses. Penalties for possession or attempted possession of firearms or dangerous weapons within federal facilities range from 1 to 5 years imprisonment. The federal criminal laws prohibit the misuse of firearms and dangerous weapons at federal facilities, including possession of other dangerous weapons within federal courthouses. The definition of "dangerous weapon" is broad and includes items like shoes, belts, and screwdrivers that could be used to inflict harm. Possessing such items in a federal courthouse can lead to practical challenges in enforcement. The misuse of firearms and dangerous weapons at federal facilities is prohibited, including possession of dangerous weapons in federal courthouses. Retaliation against federal officials has involved filing false liens and legal nuisance actions, prosecuted under federal statutes prohibiting obstruction of justice or conspiracy to inflict economic damage. Section 201 of P.L. 110-177 addresses these issues. Section 201 of P.L. 110-177 criminalizes filing false liens against federal officers, threatening them or their families, and intimidating witnesses in federal proceedings. It is a federal crime to threaten federal grand or petit jurors in order to impede or influence their service. Aiding or abetting the commission of federal crimes makes one criminally liable to the same extent as the individual who commits them. Section 202 of P.L. 110-177 prohibits making certain identifying information of federal officials, employees, witnesses, and jurors publicly available. Section 202 of P.L. 110-177 prohibits the disclosure of personal information of federal officials, employees, witnesses, and jurors with the intent to threaten or incite violence. Offenders can face up to 5 years in prison, regardless of the victims' federal or family status. The proposal may be limited by First Amendment considerations. The United States Marshals Service, part of the Department of Justice, is overseen by the Director and Marshals appointed by the President and Senate. Marshals serve four-year terms and are responsible for court security, executing warrants, protecting witnesses, managing asset forfeiture, and apprehending fugitives. The United States Marshals Service is responsible for court security, executing warrants, protecting witnesses, managing asset forfeiture, and apprehending fugitives. Section 103 calls for additional appropriations to hire more marshals for security purposes, including investigating threats against the Judiciary and high-threat trial security. The President's budget for FY2008 includes a request for $25.7 million for these purposes. The United States Marshals Service is responsible for high-threat trial security, judicial security in the Southwest Border district offices, and enforcement of the Adam Walsh Child Protection and Safety Act. Section 102 of P.L. 110-177 amends the Internal Revenue Code to provide security for the Tax Court, its judges, personnel, witnesses, and other participants. The Judicial Conference oversees rules for federal courts and ensures consultation with the Marshals Service on judicial security. Federal judges and prosecutors face threats but do not have authority to carry firearms. Marshals are responsible for security. The Attorney General is directed to report on the security of federal prosecutors, including firearm possession, within 90 days. Grants are authorized for state, territorial, and tribal prosecutors under the Violent Crime Control and Law Enforcement Act of 1994. Appropriations were last authorized for FY2000. Section 301 of P.L. 110-177 amends the Act to provide community-based grants. Section 301 of P.L. 110-177 authorizes appropriations of $20 million annually through 2011 for state witness protection programs under Part H. Sections 515 and 516 of the Omnibus Crime and Safe Streets Act of 1968 allow for discretionary grants for correctional options. A matching grant program for armored vests for law enforcement officers is authorized under Section 2501 of Title I. Additionally, amendments in P.L. 110-177 permit 10% of funds for grants to improve security for state, territorial, or tribal entities. Section 302 of P.L. 110-177 reallocates funds for grants to improve security for state, territorial, or tribal court systems, with priority given to those in greatest need. The percentage of appropriations available for corrections alternatives is reduced from 80% to 70%. Matching grants for armored vests for court officers are included, and applicants must show consideration for security in programs administered by the Department of Justice. The United States Sentencing Commission, established in 1984, provides sentencing guidelines for federal courts in criminal cases. While these guidelines are now advisory, they still hold persuasive force. The Commission can enter into contracts to fulfill its responsibilities, with appropriated funds generally available for this purpose. The United States Sentencing Commission can enter into contracts to fulfill its responsibilities, with appropriated funds generally available for this purpose. The heads of executive agencies may also contract for services that span fiscal years, enter into multi-year contracts, and make advance payments on contract obligations with sufficient security. The Administrative Office of the United States Courts and the Sentencing Commission have similar authority in this regard. Section 502 of P.L. 110-177 grants the Sentencing Commission comparable authority and eases life insurance costs for magistrate judges. Senior judges can be designated to perform judicial duties within the circuit, with the exception of appointing individuals to statutory positions. Bankruptcy judges are appointed by the circuit Court of Appeals. Bankruptcy judges, magistrate judges, and circuit judges have different appointment processes within the judicial branch. Only judges in "regular active service" and not senior judges have certain powers. An appeal to all judges of a circuit for a hearing en banc can be made by a majority vote of judges in regular active service. Senior judges can participate in en banc appeals if they were part of the original panel. Senior judges also serve on the Judicial Conference and judicial councils, with their roles determined by a majority vote of active service judges. The terms of service for judges in regular active service in a circuit are determined by a majority vote. Section 503 of P.L. 110-177 amends 28 U.S.C. 296 to grant certain senior judges powers of a judge of that court, including participation in appointment of court officers and magistrates, rulemaking, governance, and administrative matters. This amendment appears to override limitations on en banc and appointment participation. Magistrate judges are appointed by statute. The amendment to 28 U.S.C. 631(a) allows for the appointment of United States magistrate judges in the Virgin Islands, Guam, and the Northern Mariana Islands, including retired judges from regular active service. However, there is an interpretative challenge as judges in these territories retire under a different section than district court judges. The amendment allows senior United States district court judges to participate in appointing magistrate judges. It also increases judgeships on the Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals and directs a study on the impact of state and local open access laws on federal judicial security. The National Institute of Justice will conduct a study on the consequences of conviction under federal and state law.
